author: Nemo2023
title: Training needed for maternity staff
body:
I had a few issues while being induced for my first baby which I feel need to be addressed to make staff aware and get the training needed.  
I had a pessary put in early in the morning and was lying on top of my bed after it, as need to wait half an hour before getting up. I didn’t have anything on my bottom half other than a small towel across me for modesty. The curtains were pulled over. The domestic first proceeded to just come in to clean around my bed. Never to ask if it was OK to come in first before entering. I was slightly annoyed but it wasn’t an issue as I would’ve let them in anyway. The domestic then proceeded to come back in and dust over my head where I was lying, which I thought anything could’ve fell on my head and I’m pretty sure it could’ve waited half an hour.  
However, the part that bothered me the most was this time the domestic went straight out and left the curtain open where I’m in a 4-bedded ward, and I then had to get up with nothing on but this towel and try to hold this towel and pull a curtain over with other patients and their partners in the room. The bed next to me actually had a new couple arrive at this moment I had to shut the curtain. I was really not happy with this, as know that dignity is one of the first things drummed in to all members of staff when starting. This seems to me like someone who has maybe worked there for a long time and became a bit more relaxed with that, to the point that they don’t even bother.  
I did find the domestic's attitude terrible, specifically with me for some reason, as I hadn’t done anything to this person and didn’t know them beforehand. I also had an incident where I had went for a shower that morning and heard them say to their colleague very loudly that they had to go back in and clean the bathroom because I had been for a shower and brushed my teeth! This seemed to be aimed specifically at me. Now, I can assure you I never left any mess in that bathroom other than it being wet, and is that not what a bathroom is for?  
I had been there for 4 days by this point, so whether it was because I was there for so long that it was directed at me I don’t know. As i said, they've maybe worked there for that long that they don't bother now, but I don't think it’s acceptable and should be made aware that it’s not OK and how it made me feel.  
The other issue I had that really upset me while there happened after having my 4th pessary that morning and due to the codeine I had for pain relief I became constipated. After trying other things it was recommended I have an enema. Unfortunately, a major incident happened in labour ward that day which took all the doctors to there, so as a result I ended up waiting 6 and a half hours before someone could sign for this enema to be given. Surely that should be looked at for one of the midwives to be able to do as that was a long time to wait in pain and discomfort. I understand that it was unusual circumstances, however having someone else be able to sign off on it would’ve been beneficial. They’re able to give morphine etc, so why not an enema?  
However, that’s not the worst part regarding the enema situation. It eventually got signed off for me to get and was given the enema by one of the midwives, but they don’t administer it?! So I was expected as a 39-week pregnant woman to lie on my side and insert it myself! It was impossible to do and not only that but once again I was in a 4-bedded ward with other partners there and would need to do the dash across the room to the bathroom and hope no one else was in at the time.  
As a result, I had to go to the big bathroom along the corridor and lie on the floor and ask my partner to give me the enema. I cannot express to you how upsetting this was. I broke my heart like I’ve never broke my heart before to have to have your partner do something like this. Now as far as I’m aware, there’s risks with giving enemas and probably why they need signed off and is why staff have training on giving them. This is probably why the midwives don’t do them, as they haven’t had the training, but patients are expected to give them theirselves?!  
As I said, this was devastating for me and that’s coming from someone who has worked in the care industry and currently works for the NHS, so has a bit more confidence around intimate things. However, imagine if that had been a young 18-year-old girl who might’ve been on her own or a partner that wouldn’t do something like that. I don't think that’s right! I badly needed the enema, as was so uncomfortable, and it also held up the pessary process as I couldn’t get examined.  
This is not to flag up a specific member of staff, but there is clearly training needed to have the midwives able to administer the enema for patients as I’m sure I’m not the first nor the last to get constipated.  
These were the main issues I had that contributed to a very emotionally stressful experience for my first time giving birth. I don’t fault the midwives at all, but I did not have a nice experience of the whole thing and glad that it’s over.

author: ospreysx69
title: The care and treatment I received on each visit was first class
body:
I had cause to attend the treatment room at Coatbridge Health Centre on 4 occasions in April.  
The care and treatment I received on each visit was first class.  
No waiting time and the care I got from the nurses was compassionate and professional.  
I would have no hesitation in contacting them again if required.  
Thank you.

author: Subo56
title: My Angels in Blue who turned both our lives around
body:
The person I care for had a stroke in August 2022, and our lives changed overnight. He was released a few weeks later from the rehab unit at the Nottingham City Hospital on a Friday afternoon and I looked after him on my own over the weekend. I was absolutely terrified, as I thought this was it. What was I doing? This was my job now.  
However, the following Monday morning I received a call from the Stroke Team team above, my Angels in Blue who turned both our lives around. Neither of us could have done it without them. All of the team were immensely supportive and helpful. The person I care for started to become the person he once was. He will never fully regain his speech, but what we have now is miles and miles away from the position he was in after the Stroke. Thank you so much to all of the team.

author: Bell15
title: Family-centred care
body:
I would just like to send my heartfelt thanks to the two nurses running the childhood immunisation clinic at Bonnybridge HC. I’m so sorry I didn’t catch your names. I attended with my twins for their one year immunisations - 8 injections between them!  
Both of the nurses were outstanding today. I had been feeling anxious about the appointment, as at other appointments I had been questioned about not having another adult with me to help and told I needed to take another adult with me when this appointment came around - this was not possible for various reasons.  
But it was never mentioned and both nurses were great at just getting on with it, and having twins was not an issue whatsoever. They put me at ease straight away, were friendly, chatty, personable, informative, looked at the bigger picture all whilst providing family-centred care and getting the job down with no fuss.  
Thank you so much and I hope this gets back to you. I really hope we have you both again when we come back for our pre school boosters

author: Frustrated of Norfolk
title: My mother's experience
body:
Mum was taken to Northampton General Hospital after a fall. X-rays were taken but apparently not reviewed, and she was discharged to home by ambulance the next day (we had no advance warning of this). She was told the bed was needed for someone who needed it more than her.  
Continuous falls over the next 3 weeks, as mum tried to be independently mobile.  
Community nurses arranged for admission to Northampton General via A&E. By then she was unable to walk or even stand at all.  
She spent the whole of that day in A&E on a chair in the waiting area, and that night on a chair in the corridor, and the next day on a trolley in a cubicle.  
She was eventually moved to a ward (Eleanor ward.) The nurse phoned to say Mum had fallen in the ward. Finally (it appears) her x-rays were checked and fracture diagnosed. The previous x-rays were reviewed and a hairline fracture detected (from 3 weeks previously).  
Surgery performed, but but due to damage caused by so many falls, a normal hip replacement could not be performed, and so a girdle stone procedure was done. Moved to Cedar orthopaedic ward  
Over the next 3 weeks Mum got Covid, (and was moved to Willow ward), C Diff, and multiple UTI’s, so no physiotherapy was given.  
She was then moved to Danetre Hospital for intensive physio. Built up shoe supplied.  
Mum is currently still there, but not physically able to come home. She has no mobility at all. We will have to find a residential care place for her.

author: MazMigd
title: Great staff
body:
I dislocated my knee and the ambulance were great and once in a&e the ambulance stayed with me and the staff for a while helping. The staff at Wigan were lovely and had good energy. The pain relief was well medicated and looked after. The accident occurred at 5:20pm, i was at the hospital by 7pm and got discharged between 12-2am.  
Happy with the service and grateful.

readBy.name: North West Ambulance Service NHS Trust

author: craterqy64
title: GP experience
body:
I want to acknowledge the fantastic care I received at my GP practice this morning. When I called I got through to reception after a bit of a wait and was given an appointment the next morning at 9 am.  
I saw Dr Berry from Kingsway medical Practice in Glasgow. Her care could not have been better! She listened, asked what I thought, treated me with interest, kindness and compassion. She looked things up and showed me online photographs which helped me to understand and feel confident about her diagnosis. She made a clear treatment plan with me and I knew what to do next if it improved or deteriorated. She also helped with a second issue I raised in the same helpful, efficient and inclusive way. I had never met Dr Berry before but I can see she displays the same, extremely high standard of care I have experienced with every other member of the medical and nursing team, as well as the very important reception staff. Thanks so much. I feel very grateful for this excellent team.

author: Sparkels46
title: Stepping stones
body: I just wanted to say a huge thanks to Ryan and renew. This has been such an experience and if anyone needs recovery, step on the stones heading towards ryan at renew. No one ever wants to leave:-( its a family of hope, openness, transparency. You can be at your own self on these groups. Well done Ryan, thank you so much.

author: Satisfied and Content
title: Visit to Breast Clinic Royal Free
body: I had to attend the breast clinic with my 18 year old daughter and wanted to express my thanks to the well run department. Everyone from the welcoming receptionist to the consultant, radiographer and patient nursing staff were all very kind and sensitive. Its so convenient to have everything in the one department. Within 2 hours she had been seen, scanned, diagnosed and discharged. Thank you all

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

links.id: very well looked after and cared for

author: incognito
title: The nurses and doctors were friendly and professional
body:
I was admitted to Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy, following a reaction to antibiotics that I needed to fight a bacterial infection in my foot. After spending some time in the admissions unit (service and care was also good here despite it being very busy, noisy, and the obvious lack of nurses) I was transferred to Ward 51 for an overnight stay for intravenous antibiotics.  
The ward was a world away from the admissions ward - it was modern, clean, and quiet. I had my own room and a greater choice of what to watch on TV than I have at home! The nurses on Ward 51 were professional, caring and quietly got on with their job. They went the extra mile to find me an ice pack for my foot and crept in quietly during the night to change my medication.  
Once the doctors were happy that I was not allergic to the new medicine they started to plan how to get me home whilst still requiring IV antibiotics. Thankfully I was accepted to attend the OPAT clinic - Outpatient Parenteral Antibiotic Therapy. What a wonderful model of care available to people in Fife.  
The OPAT team are amazing - my foot was actively monitored for change/improvement every day, the cannulas were inserted and changed without drama or pain, the nurses and doctors were friendly and professional and there was even time for some banter! And of course plenty of tea and biscuits while you receive your antibiotics always helps.  
But seriously, despite the overhead of travelling to the hospital every day, this model of care was perfect for my situation. I wasn't taking up a valuable bed, I felt supported, well cared for, and also had plenty of time for proper rest at home. The OPAT team are a credit to NHS Fife and I am very thankful for their care.

author: Mah5678
title: This is a new life for me
body:
On my arrival to DCDS the staff were absolutely brilliant with me, they were very welcoming. They offered me food although I could not eat the first day. I was told where everything was.  
I was anxious on 1st day, still a little on 2nd day I was going to stay in my room, then I thought I need to go to groups, once I started doing them I got to know the other patients which really helped me with my confidence. The more I attended the groups, the more I enjoyed learning about other peoples experiences.  
Getting to know other people, was like a little family group. I have barely sat in my room, as I engage with the other residents.  
The medication was available if I needed more but didn't want to over do it, I stuck to the requirements.  
I have really enjoyed the meditation, and I will continue to do when I leave. I also enjoyed NA and CA coming in as people had been through similar experiences.  
If you ever needed clean towels, they were supplied. If ever a problem, it was resolved straight away. A very relaxed atmosphere. I didn't feel any tension. I felt very comfortable.  
I felt very reassured when I first arrived, as the staff kept checking I was okay which really helped me.  
I will be leaving here with so much positive thoughts and energy which I haven't had for about 3 years. The only thing that could be improved was the drainage in the shower rooms.  
I wish I could stay longer but have to get back for my animals.

author: gemini123
title: Bleeding after intercorse
body: Started bleeding everytime after sexual intercorse. Made me feel scared something was wrong.  So went to the sexual health clinic to find out what was going on. Very good and very friendly and reasuring, they did a full screening for me to rule everything out. Now to just await for all my results back. Recieved some results which are all fine. Also advised further instructions on what to do when i received all results back.

author: Pad44
title: Hospital at Home, Western Health & Social Care Trust
body: An admission to A&E in SWAH on 24/04/23 necessitated a 7 day regime of IV antibiotics. While in A&E we were introduced to the Hospital at Home scheme. The scheme was fully explained ie patient would return home, nurses would visit 3 times per day for the duration of the treatment to administer IV antibiotics as well as checking vital signs and taking samples for lab tests. In addition, there would be home visits from a doctor to monitor the patient’s progress. We returned home and treatment started.The whole process was fantastic. The nurses and doctor were professional, efficient and a breath of fresh air - all had an absolutely wonderful bedside manner. They explained every step and all the options available. They gave advice and left us feeling happy and confident. At all times we felt we were in safe hands. We also had a telephone number to call if we had any problems. Finally, we had a visit from the team Pharmacist who very helpfully went through all the patient’s medications to ensure everything was appropriate and given at the best times.The week passed without any issues.This is a fantastic service and a win-win. The hospital had a free bed and saved on 24 hour staff care and associated costs, while the patient had the appropriate treatment in the comfort of his own surroundings. Finally, the family was saved the time, cost and inconvenience of travelling to the hospital for limited visiting. We also knew at all times how our loved one was. This scheme should be more widely available. While there will always be a place for a hospital for emergency, acute and surgical intervention, I would never consider leaving anyone in a hospital bed if they could have this quality of appropriate treatment in the comfort of their own home.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: angiewo
title: Thanks to staff for getting me through
body:
After having a bad experience in the past I was petrified of having my eye injections again and I would like to thank ANDREW ( the injector !!) for giving me a PAINLESS INJECTION also Sarah, Janet and not forgetting Will who was observing for helping me through this ordeal. Janet and Penny and ALL the staff are absolutely brilliant.  
If I have forgotten anybody I apologise. Thank you EXMOOR UNIT AT NORTH DEVON HOSPITAL for getting me through this frightening experience and I feel comforted that you are there for me when I need you

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: aoiy23
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: As a carer for my elderly parent who is a patient on this ward (Gillis ward)
body:
As a carer for my elderly parent who is a patient on this ward (Gillis ward) and suffers from dementia as well as several other complex medical conditions, I have discovered that a number of the nurses, medical professionals, and doctors on this ward are incredibly helpful and have provided my father with the best support and care possible. They take their time thoroughly describing the diagnosis and recommended treatments, and they make sure I understand. I also value the rapid advice on how to take your medications properly.  
When caring for him, things can become overwhelming, so I value the clear, comprehensible, and patient approach. Many thanks

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cygnus54
title: Poor communication /colorectal cancer care
body:
I have recently been diagnosed with Colon cancer. From the time of diagnosis at colonoscopy , to finally having surgical removal of the tumour, after a lengthy wait of almost 4 weeks, my care has been empathetic and kind and communication very good. My inpatient care was excellent.  
However, since discharge from hospital the communication has been woeful. I was told to expect results from the pathology at 10 -14 days post operatively . Two, and then almost 3 weeks went by with no word. No contact from the district nurses regarding my wounds occurred in spite of my making contact with them. I tried to ring the colorectal cancer nurse service but they were too busy to speak to me! Nobody touched base to ask how I was faring.  
At almost 3 weeks post op I finally received a phone call from the cancer nurse ( not the surgeon himself) . I now require chemotherapy. I requested information regarding timescales for this and was informed about the ‘targets ‘ that the cancer service works to. There seemed to be a complete disregard for the inevitable anxiety felt by a patient in this situation - fulfilling targets is the LAST thing on my mind - I am aware that the longer one waits for treatment the poorer the longer term outcomes. No empathy whatever from the CRC nurse I spoke to . In fact they became very short and spoke over me when I tried to ask questions.  
I feel that especially when results are delayed that some communication from the team would take so little time, but have a huge impact on patient well being , and allay some of the inevitable anxiety that comes with such a diagnosis. I have been left feeling that I am just a number , and that as long as the targets for treatment are met that any attempt at holistic care is unnecessary . I hope that the team will reflect upon my experience and try to improve the care for other patients in similar circumstances.

author: castorfh77
title: timely, friendly and compassionate care
body:
I attended the radiology department for an ultrasound scan at Omagh Hospital. I was apprehensive.  
I got booked in promptly. I was taken in for scan within a few minutes by a friendly member of staff called Roisin. She carried out scan and reassured me that everything looked ok.  
I was impressed by the timely, friendly and compassionate care I received by Roisin

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: fornaxqp38
title: Post heart attack nhs care
body: The wonderful, care provided by the many people involved in coronary care working in NHS Fife and NHS Tayside has been amazing. I’m grateful to all.  I’m particularly grateful to Specialist Cardio-Nurse Practitioner, Julie, based in Ladybank, Fife.  Her approachability, sensibility, kind understanding reassurance are life affirming. Her most excellent, wholistic approach is an example for us all.

author: castorjs36
title: They were terrific
body:
I've had serious surgery and brain operations and two cataract operations. All turned out well.  
I just want to say though, that the care package could not have been better-it was absolutely superb. And there are two people in particular I want to mention-Craig, who is in, charge of physio and his assistant, Rhona. Both really were terrific, not just in taking care physical care, but in taking of the psychological side as well.  
They were terrific.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: stonedp39
title: Exercise during and after cancer
body:
I was diagnosed with breast cancer, and the amazing cancer nurses gave me a library of booklets to read through to help me on my journey, and among these there was information about the importance of exercise in the progression towards good health. They recommended that I get in touch with Joe to assist me with this.  
As I was just about to have my surgery, there was no time to start my course of exercise classes at that stage, but Joe asked questions about both my physical wellbeing and my mental approach to what was happening. I then was able to join the online classes a little while after my surgery.  
It was good to be able to do this from the comfort of my own home, and to have the discipline of a weekly class that was not too high impact. I felt that Joe was attentive to all the people in his class, making sure that they were not taking any risks with their health in terms of any weakness, balance issues, over exertion etc. He corrected us if we were not exercising correctly, but gave support and encouragement when we got it right! I feel the course would be a very supportive tool for anyone who felt isolated by their illness, and that can only be a good thing.  
I finished my course today, and my level of fitness has improved a good deal since my first day in class, so that says a lot!  
[Unsure about 'Treatment']

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Waterman1234
title: Helped me through a very distressing time
body:
I was in extreme discomfort, and unable to pass urine.  
I received treatment initially at RAH Paisley Outpatients department, and more recently at VOL Alexandria.  
On each occasion the standard of care I received has been excellent, and has helped me through a very distressing time.  
I cannot praise the various members of staff highly enough, and I will be forever in their debt.  
A heartfelt Thank you to each and everyone involved.  
[Unhappy with 'Staff skills']  
  
[Happy with 'Staff attitude']

readBy.name: Office of Jenni Minto, MSP for Argyll and Bute

author: Coco91
title: Everything was explained in detail
body: Went in for a colonoscopy for investigation after a positivee q fit test. I was absolutely petrified. The staff were absolutely brilliant and had so much patience for everyone on the ward. Everything was explained in detail what was happening and why it was happening. I wasn't waiting a long time to go in and was seen really quickly and given a bed. Went in for the procedure really quick aswell and was out in no time. I Moved back a few months ago after living in Wales for 17 years and this is the first time I felt I understood what was going. The staff at the day procedure unit were absolutely brilliant. An absolute credit to the NHS.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jilbh93
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Long Wait in ED
body:
Visited Out of Hours as I couldn't get an appointment with my GP and was sent over to ED at 2.30pm. I had a long wait in ED and wasn't admitted to the ward until nearly 12 hours later.  
My care has been good since I was admitted and the staff have been awful good to me. The food has been top class.  
I've been kept informed regarding my treatment and have had some test results back and just waiting on one more blood test.  
I can't say one thing wrong about any of it.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jilbh93
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Kidney Problems
body: Admitted over 3 weeks ago as I was having problems with my kidneys. My mobility has been poor and I'm currently waiting on respite as I live by myself and my mobility needs to be a bit better before I can go home.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Markyp
title: Continuous pain and no further idea
body:
I injured my thigh playing squash 5+ years ago, after several appointments with GP I was referred to MSK who suggest Physio, that did not go well! after my third session where there was an audible pop and tears to my eyes with dizziness, I was referred to MRI, first scan was shallow and showed little if anything. The specialist suggested a deep scan, then lock down happened, I had the scan (over 3 years ago) I have still not heard back and my emails and voicemails have gone unanswered absolutely disgusted with them!  
I now have continuous pain and no further idea.

title: Great practice
body: I visited this morning and the new team were excellent, I had face to face appointment with Dr and he listened to what I had to say and gave me a good consultation. He was very friendly and hopefully he will build the surgery to get better again.

title: Brilliant service
body: The staff are friendly and supportive. Nothing is too hard and they go out of their way to make you feel comfortable

title: Good practice
body: I had a appointment this morning, the receptionist was very friendly and I saw the new Dr face to face and he actually listened to me and the consultation was excellent, he was also a friendly Dr. He has got a really tough job in getting the surgery up and running properly again which I am sure he will do with the new team in time. So far I have had no problem with new team

author: gammahs35
title: Recent hospital admission
body:
I am unfortunately a frequent visitor to the Royal hospital for children Edinburgh with my daughter, due to medical conditions.  
On this admission my child is here for just now, I have discovered that the hospital canteen within the building does not serve any form of decent meal on a lunch time; for example macaroni, instead now it is soup or a pastry.  
I would like to know how this is seen as acceptable to serve to parents, and also sometimes patients that do not like the food trolley meals.  
On the back of that, there was also the option to have the choice of the small café on the ground floor which now is also closed for the foreseeable future.  
Again this was somewhere to have a hot drink and a small light lunch. Service was also quick and pleasant staff, which is more than can be said for the main canteen.  
Quick service with easy accessibility is what is required most of the time for parents when in hospital with their child as they don't want to leave them for too long.  
Given that the small café has closed, there is the voluntary shop that has options and there is a coffee machine. I'm there, but can't get that until 3.30pm so how is that any good to visitors and parents, along side staff.

title: Pleasant Staff
body: Reception staff very helpful. Consultation with nurse put me at ease and explained procedure. I have always found the surgery visits to be well staffed and a clean environment.

title: Wonderful support and service
body: The Allan Practice Team has gone the “extra mile” to care for my wife since she was diagnosed with a terminal condition in February. Despite being encumbered by poor processes and disconnected systems they have found ways to make sure that my wife gets the best care possible. Friendly and helpful people all doing their best within a NHS system that needs overhauling to retain the good parts and get rid of waste, duplication, rework and inefficiency.

author: Brian 72
title: Poor treatment and staff that don't seem to care.
body:
I have seen a patient that left Wishaw General Hospital after having had a stoke making good progress and feeling very positive about their future go so backwards in their recovery and mental health. They now look like they did on day one after their stroke.  
To be honest, I believe the Strathclyde ward at Airbles Road Centre is no better than an undertaker's waiting room. In my experience, patients are generally left to stagnate in the rooms.  
Whoever heard of the Doctor reviews once a week (if you're lucky) so nothing really gets done from one week to the other.  
Relatives concerns are not followed up up on, or handed over for action.  
Patients don't really seem to be encouraged to use the day room, which itself is not a very pleasant room to be in.  
If you have a relative in Wishaw Hospital, please don't allow the hospital to move them to this forgotten corner of the NHS care system.

author: Daniel823
title: Terrible service for my mother
body:
My mother is in this ward and has lost her phone and I’ve been calling everyday for an update, but each new day each new group of staff are only hearing the story as a new report and haven’t communicated about the loss of my Mother's phone within the Chelmer ward as this is a contained space and my mother told them that her phone went missing and me writing this me is they don’t know where the phone is.  
My mum has come in due to what I believe is mismanagement of her medication from trigiminal neuralgia. I don't think the doctors have done a background check on her back diagnostics on what the issue may be, and I believe they have been pumping her with new medicine until they find an appropriate diagnostic. But I think if they'd done real research they would know what the cause was .  
An independent doctor came in without knowledge of her previous when asked on the phone and made an assessment to keep her in based on her not knowing which date it is. I am different from a lot of people in my family that comes in, I want this message to get to the right person, as I will go as far as starting a petition for change.

author: ERDD
title: The support offered falls way short
body:
It took social work 6 months to decide that 3 hours' care per week would be sufficient to cope with all the added needs of having terminal bone cancer. As the cancer is predominantly spinal, the limitations and pain are rather significant. As it is terminal, the emotional turmoil is rather significant.  
As it is Shawpark Resource Centre making the decision, the support offered is, in standing with their other decisions regards support for me I have experienced, rather significant in its falling way short of anything that could scratch the support needed for someone with diagnosis of terminal bone cancer. Given the short life expectancy and time Shawpark will take, I will likely be dead before they deal with my appeal.

title: The best children’s ward
body: My son had a routine operation where he was treated so well. The staff were so caring and attentive. As a parent you couldn’t ask for more. Well done Amazon ward. What a great team of people.

title: Excellent practise
body: I had an excellent consultation with the woman doctor. She listened and was very kind & knowledgeable. I felt very well looked after. My partner and I have been with this surgery for decades. All the staff from the receptionist, nurses to the doctors are amazing. They are empathetic, extremely helpful and reassuring. We feel very fortunate to have such a great practice. Unfortunately we realise they are under enormous pressure yet somehow they still deliver a wonderful standard of care. Thank you to all the staff for everything you have done for us. We are so grateful.

title: Great practice
body: Recently called for some help regarding my son. The receptionist was really caring and helpful in talking through some options. The GP seen was fantastic- read the vibes during the appointment and had such a caring nature.

title: Fantastic service and staff
body: My parents are registered with Westside Medical Centre, I highly commend the service they have received as patients. They have always received fantastic and efficient care. The medical practitioners alongside the practice manager and staff do a truly amazing job. Well done and thank you for all you do

title: Outstanding support and care
body:
My wife and I were under the support of the EPU department due to a miscarriage. I cannot express in words how we were both taken care of and supported. 

The time and care given to us as a family was overwhelming. We have been devastated but their kind nature and time I cannot thank them enough.

Hannah &  Stacey

title: Amazing service
body:
Sent an email to surgery requesting a consultation. Follow up phone call was literally within 5minutes and an invitation to attend the surgery that morning.
Initially seen by a healthcare assistant who did basic obs, then seen by 2 trainee medical students who took a detailed history of my issue, and then seen by a paramedic practitioner who arranged medication and also investigative scans at a later date. So impressed with the prompt service & treatment - amazing.

title: Very welcoming
body: Had an appointment and reception staff were very friendly and the dr I seen was amazing and explained everything to me and will follow up

title: Fabulous nurse service
body: I recently had an appointment with the practice nurse. She looked at a small growth I had near my neck. Immediately she referred me to have my growth looked at by a dermatologist . I later saw a surgeon who sent a sample for a biopsy. I had the result on Wednesday. I had bowens disease. I wish to thank all the team I saw for their professionalism, especially the nurse. I really appreciate all you did for me x

title: Great Service
body: I have had a condition which has meant I have needed to see a clinician several times in the last few weeks.  I got the appointments and referrals that I needed when I needed them and all the staff that I encountered have been helpful, polite, kind and considerate, I could not have asked for better care.  Thank you everyone for the hard work you are all doing to keep us all safe and well.

author: deltaec58
title: Ultrasound Plus biopsy
body: When I was taken into the room, I felt a little uneasy as I was not too sure what the procedure would be. I was asked to sit on the bed and the radiographer took me through the steps of the procedure. I was asked the normal questions - name, age and address. I was also asked how I was feeling and reassured that the procedure would not take too long. I was also shown the probe and the clicking noise that it would make when procedure was done. I could not have asked for two better radiology nurses. Both made me feel relaxed and very calm during my time there. Once the procedure was done, I was asked to wait for around 10 minutes and the radiographer would check on me before going home.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Amazing
body: My time of pregnancy and childbirth was amazing and Chelsea and Westminster played a vital role in making it amazing. Everything was so appropriate and professional, because of which my whole time became easy and hassle free. Despite of covid restrictions, my childbirth experience was great and easy. Thanks everyone for being there in time of need.

readBy.name: Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Superb dentistry department
body: I needed a molar tooth extracting.  The entire experience, from the admissions secretaries, right through to my dental surgeon, assisting doctor & nurse, were superb!  What made a potentially frightening experience as bearable as possible.  72 hours after surgery, no pain, no pain killers needed and no infection.  I can't thank these lovely people enough and commend them on their high-quality work.

title: Oh I see
body:
An impressively streamlined process from booking an appointment to seeing an eye specialist.
Conveniently located clinic next to shopping centre with local transport hub.
Able to book online with minimum of fuss.
Rapid turn round of results.

title: Excellent service
body: Received a call back. Staff always friendly and helpful. The appointment service is much improved now, morning and afternoon availability. Doctors and nurses are good and thorough. Thank you.

author: Kirsten536
title: Above and beyond
body: I am very thankful to the staff in MKU who was looking after my mum. I am now living in Australia and my mum was never good with technology to FaceTime. The staff would help my Mum answer her phone or call me back if connection was lost so we could FaceTime. If I called in the middle of night they would update me on her day or if she was awake let us chat. Thanks for all the care.

title: Great doctor & nurses
body:
When visiting the clinic for a vasectomy, understandably I was extremely nervous, scared, worried and everything else that goes through a mans head with this procedure. 
The doctor could see the worry on my face and instantly put me at ease and reassured me of his expertise and how common this procedure is. He didnt put any pressure on me and explained the whole procedure right through and checked I was happy with everything before going ahead. 
The nurses were also brilliant, they put me and ease and were very comforting while in the clinic. After what I thought was going to be a traumatic experience, it was surely was not thanks to the staff. Very professional, kind and polite. Thank you.

title: Wonderful Doctor and Nurse
body: My appointment took a bit of a scary turn and although I was becoming panicked the Doctor was amazing in reassuring me and discussing what our next steps were. She was very clear, friendly and helpful and has been very quick at getting results for me.

author: Twinkle999
title: I was made to feel like I was making this up
body:
I was out this afternoon. Took a seizure out of pain. This can happen. NIAS showed up and later on accused me of faking the seizure as it didn't last more than a minute. I was only sent home from a second stay in hospital 2 weeks ago with inflammation of the pancreas (PANCREATITIS) and alongside a rise in my LFTS and enlarged bile duct which are still being looked into.  
I was made to feel like I was making this up and was told to go, because if I went to hospital there would be a lengthy wait and I’d be sent home anyway, something that I feel paramedics shouldn’t say. I was also accused of not taking my regular medication for seizures, which I’m not on due to the fact that taking epilepsy medication can be harmful to non-epileptics. This was decided by a neurologist.  
I’m sick of being accused of faking seizures. This has to stop. I feel like I’m being harassed by some people for things that are out of my control.

title: Good experience
body: I registered here, after a poor experience at my previous practice. The day my registration went through a receptionist was very helpful, and called to arrange a new patient check-up, and also helped me sort out my repeat prescriptions. I have also managed to easily set up accessing online services and am really glad I am now registered with this practice. They seem easy to get hold of too.

title: Excellent service
body: The service was exemplary - car to deliver me to and from the appointment, courteous and helpful staff, friendly and sympathetic nurses and surgeon and the procedure was painless.

title: Excellent service
body: The service was exemplary - car to deliver me to and from the appointment, courteous and helpful staff, friendly and sympathetic nurses and surgeon and the procedure was painless.

title: Great staff and very quick in responding
body:
So far having recently changed to this practice! Wow! What a great set up. Staff are friendly and reception always manned which at my last surgery there was always queues to book in. 
I struggled to see a doctor face to face at me last surgery but here not a problem. 
Thank you

title: Professional and caring
body: First time knee injection for osteoarthritis. Doctor took his time to explain everything and to put me at ease. Thank you.

author: yellowhw37
title: Really poor midwife support
body:
Went in to Ninewells to be induced with my first baby a few months ago. Got put on a busy bay in ward 38 which had antenatal women and new mums and babies there. I didn't know I would be with new babies and this did not make for a relaxing night and also they had emergency sections which was awful to hear and did not make me relaxed at all.  
The midwife told us we would have to stay on the bay with the new mums until I was in proper labour and that I couldn't go to labour ward until then, which made me really worried about managing the pain! All the internal exams were just behind a curtain in the bay of the busy ward.  
In labour ward I had another midwife who seemed very junior and stood in the corner gossiping with their student most of the time. The rest of the time they just watched the monitor and baby heart trace and didn't seem interested in supporting you at all. Advised not to have any pain relief yet, even though my pain was terrible. Not sure if this poor support is because of staffing there, but the midwifes were really not supportive or caring and we were really disappointed with the experience. Maybe it would have been different with different midwifes.

author: Home_Fix
title: Pre-assessment
body:
I was truly taken care of by the PRI Pre-assessment Team.  
They were very friendly and professional and explained all of what was happening. The team included a student from Dundee University who is certainly on the right career path. Sorry I can’t remember all the team names -they certainly work well together.  
Thank you.

title: Impossible to Get Through by Telephone
body: Called the surgery at 0840 this morning to clarify an ambiguous text I had received regarding a repeat prescription.  Held on the line for 50 minutes during which period I was allegedly 'Number 1 in the queue'.  Had to hang up in order to attend another appointment.  Called back at 0925 and found myself 'Number 14 in the queue'. On this occasion, held on the line for 1 hour 3 minutes before simply being cut off.  I am temporarily immobile following surgery, so in the end had to ask my wife to take time off work to drive me to Sutton Benger surgery to talk to someone face to face.  Between them, the reception and dispensary staff were able to resolve the issue, but this does not detract from the fact that I had wasted nearly 2 hours waiting on the phone.  Ironically, there is a 'You Said, We Did' poster in the surgery extolling the virtues of the new faster, telephone system - but, for me, this was a very poor experience indeed.

title: E consult
body: Although I see the benefits of this service it is only available between 12 and 6pm and on the last 2 consecutive days the system has shut down before 3:30. If the point is to encourage the use of the service and then be unable to provide it is frustrating. The lack of the service then potentially forces patients to look to alternative options to the disadvantage of the whole service

title: Great service
body: Very efficient service. Seen on time, compassionate and efficient staff. Very happy with my experience

title: Frustrating
body: I’m trying to get an appointment for the annual review of an operation I had almost 4 years ago. As yet I haven’t had one review. I had blood / urine tests four weeks ago and I’m struggling to find out the results. When booking the online appointment it clearly states requests submitted before 4pm would be responded to within the same working day …. almost 36hours later I’m still waiting. When I phoned reception the person I spoke with was rude and unhelpful, I’m able to take care of myself - I do however feel for the elderly and more vulnerable members of our community who can’t navigate such rudeness and hostility.

author: Darren Meager
title: Gave me lots of useful tools
body: Arrived at the detox with a little bit of anxiety going on not knowing what to expect. Was made welcome when I arrived. Was a little shy to do groups at first due to my anxiety but soon came over that. Was feeling ill for the first few days but soon got over that. The group work was good and gave me lots of useful tools to take away with me.

title: Day admission: Wizard Ward
body:
My daughter visited Wizard ward today for an anaesthetised MRI and I felt the visit deserved a review. 
From the time the MRI was booked, I have received a very thorough information letter, telling me the do’s & dont’s, and what to expect. I also received a call confirming the appointment. Then yesterday I  received a pre-appointment/pre assessment call, to further prepare me, check on my child and allow me to answer questions, they also directed me to a video link to watch with my child to help prepare her for the visit. 
Today,on arrival, we was greeted and talked through the whole process again, explained the routine and given a clean and comfy cubicle with a bed to wait in. 
There was also a lovely open planned play area being lead by a play coordinator, who actively went from bed to bed and used props to demonstrate to the children the procedure in a very child friendly way; she also had sticker charts to map out each part of their journey with them as the complete it. Honestly this lady was everywhere you looked, reaching each child and parent and yet somehow gave each child so much attention.
Then there was a barrage of incredible nurses, who were very present, warm, approachable and fluent in the language of child. They had such a good system between them, they did not miss a beat in the care given. 
Then to top it all off, the Doctor doing the Anaesthetic popped down to meet everyone individually and discuss the process, the options and to answer any questions. When my daughter fell asleep just before Anaesthetic was due, he quickly reassessed the plan to decide how best not to disturb her sleep to minimise distress. Again there was a whole team of keen and willing people in that department too, also all very present and helpful. 
I was sent for promptly when my child came out of the MRI so she didn’t wake up alone. 
Once back on the ward, my daughter was observed continuously, and again the Anaesthetist popped in to check on her recovery. She was not rushed to wake up, but once awake she was offered food and drink and was only allowed home until they was entirely happy with her state. 
Honestly, wizard ward is smashing it. I can’t speak for the entire hospital, but since my daughter become a pedeatrics outpatient in January, she has been in a couple of times (she’s also stayed on phoenix ward) and she has received incredible care. Nothing but impressed so far. 
Thank you to all the paediatrics @broomfields

author: falconsd54
title: Depression
body:
I suffer from severe anxiety and depression for several years now. Low moods and “what’s the point”.  
I feel like this first session was good and it wasn’t as daunting as I thought it would be, looking forward to the future appointments.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Shocking
body:
Waited on line for 45 mins to be told I could not book an appointment for an injection I have every three months.
I am going away on the 14th May. I was told that no appointment
was available. I was also told that I cannot book an appointment for two weeks in advance. I was then told to ring on Friday the 12th May to book an appointment for when I return of holiday. I told the receptionist I dont get back until 28th. My maths isnt great but that is 16days from the 12th plus days for an appointment.
Seriously shocking service. Looks like they make rules up as they answer a call

author: sagittariuses53
title: fabulous Nurses
body: i have custody of my granddaughter who is disabled, i do struggle with her care sometimes, and could not have gotten her so far without the help and suport of two of her nurses Lorraine and Lynne. thay have been my rock in all aspects, even when it wasn't something that thay deal with, thay pointed me in the right direction or sometimes even delt with it for me. Last February my granddaughter was very ill and thay were switching off the machine she was on to breath, it was devastating Lorraine ask me if she could be their with her as she has known my granddaughter from birth. happy ending my granddaughter opened her eyes and fought her way back to good health, Yippee!! and will be 18 soon i am so sad to be losing them as my granddaughter is transferring to adult services soon, thank you Lorraine and Lynne for everything xx

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Inconsiderate Physiotherapist. No compassion.…
body: I was recommended by my GP here for physio. I got rejected by the physiotherapist. She said that she already cancelled my appointment. I was late for 5 to 10 mins as I couldn’t find the place. She can see that I was in pain and at the moment, she doesnt have any patient. I don’t understand. No compassion and no consideration. She said she called the next patient and she is just waiting for the person. I said, I didn’t receive any call, and she said she would normally call but not everytime. Horrible experience. I’m now here in pain trying to get hold off my GP so I can get to a physio. I don’t normally post negative review. But i’d like to notify people about this and make sure they come in 1 hour before so they wont waste time and make sure that they just dont cancel your appointment. I hope the physiotherapist woman reads this and be more considerate with patients.  Very terrible experience. I was crying on the way back home because of pain and mostly because of the bad experience and the way the Physiotherapist talked to me in this clinic

title: Amazing
body: After our son became really unwell we took him “Roman” to Bolton hospital and they took us in straight away. Roman had a very high temp and wasn’t responsive at all. All his needs was met! Straight onto antibiotics, the people in the ward was all amazing polite & lovely people. Even the training nurses was so nice! It all came back that Roman has a virus called rosyola that’s a mild virus in comparison to lots of others. All his tests was done so good and fast. (Big thanks to the porters that push people up and down that long steep corridor to you guys are awesome) thanks to the doctors that took there time listening to us as parents and reacting to what we said. I’d never hesitate to bring our kids here or myself…. Thanks for everything it really was our privilege being under your care.

title: Awful, terrible service for patients
body: I was referred to the hospital and had an initial neurosurgery appointment in February. The doctor was hopeless. He basically told me as a young, 30 year old female, that I should not try having children and would never exercise again. He would offer no advice as he had not seen my MRI imaging (the MRI scan had been undertaken two months previously). I was offered a further appointment two months later in April. That was subsequently cancelled, no explanation offered. Re-made for May, then that was cancelled. I am now told I have to wait until June - several months later. Meanwhile I continue to suffer a lot of pain. How can the hospital just leave patients waiting for months on end, with no explanation offered. I have wasted several days off work attending the useless appointment, and trying to re-schedule. Clearly the consultant's time is more important than those of his patients.

title: Terrible
body:
I was referred to Reed Wellbeing through my general practice for their diabetes prevention programme after developing gestational diabetes in pregnancy. In my initial phone consultation, I specified that due to childcare, I couldn't attend anything until after 3pm. Despite that, they offered me a course at 11am and asked me to call if it worked. I did not call as it obviously didn't work. They then left me an answer machine message while I was on holiday (so they would have had international dial) offering me yet another course prior to 3pm. I didn't call back as I was on holiday, so the next day I got a text saying they were referring me back to the general practice because they'd tried to contact me "several times" despite the fact that no messages implied I must reply.

I emailed them to stop them referring me back to the general practice and they claimed they'd also emailed me. I stated that I'd received zero emails and who were they emailing. That question was ignored, but I was put onto a 6pm course.

I attended the first session this week and I was not impressed in the slightest and wish to explain why.

The reason for my referral is that I developed gestational diabetes which means you're more susceptible to diabetes when you're older.. In the course I attended, I was the only person there that this was the case for.

In this introductory session, we were informed that the aim over the course was to lose 5%-10% body fat and then they weighed everyone in the session to work out what that would be.

This on its own alarmed me. I am a clothing size 10 and not overweight in the slightest - someone needs to review these sessions as it cannot be a one size fits all.

We were then shown a food diary section, with a column for calories and whilst the lady said calories are not compulsory, I found it to be very triggering and encouraging a very unhealthy relationship with food.

Next, we were told that we need to track our steps every day and whilst I'm on board with encouraging mobility, again I don't think bringing in a tracking obsession is healthy.

So in short - track my weight, track my calories and track my steps, which for the most part for me, encourages an unhealthy number obsession and it really upset me, especially when I absolutely do not need to lose weight.

We were also told of "quick wins" eg cut out alcohol- I don't drink. Cut down on red meat - I don't eat red meat etc etc.

Not once were we asked about our wellbeing or how we felt about this in the session and to top it off I was told I should have received an email on the sessions which I obviously didn't receive because admin is emailing an email that's not mine clearly.

I raised this and was told someone would call me to rectify this. Today I got a text not a call that I cannot reply to telling me to check my spam mail which I found to be patronising. There is nothing in my spam and still nobody has asked me what my email even is.

author: scasey200
title: Recent day surgery admission
body:
I cannot describe how amazing the care has been today within the Day Surgery unit at RAH. I was cared for a team of staff including nurses Sam and Sandie who made sure that I had a comfortable journey through from check in to recovery and discharge home.  
All went very smoothly, the team were very thorough with pre and post surgery checks. Constantly making sure you all your needs were met. This is the NHS at its best. I am a clinician myself so can see the negative and critical side of care. However, I can honestly sing the praises of all involved in my care today.

author: aoiy23
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: I was worried about my surgery but immediately eased
body:
I was worried about my surgery to remove cataracts, but it was immediately eased. The overall atmosphere was pleasant and comforting. I was provided with a cup of tea in the area where I was waiting. At every level, things were thoroughly explained and handled with kindness. The entire team took fantastic care of me, and my procedure went without any pain. My healing process was carefully explained to me in another room before I was gently led back to my husband in the bay.  
I would wholeheartedly advise anyone in need of cataract surgery to not be worried about coming to Craigavon Area Hospital as they have provided me with first class care. Each staff member was understanding, considerate, polite, and competent.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Priya P
title: Excellent Care and Efficient Work
body:
I came in to the A&E department as a suspected meningitis case as I have previously suffered from it before and was worried my symptoms were the same.  
As a staff member of the hospital myself I cannot fault the care I received from my colleagues around the hospital.  
During my admission into Northwick Park Hospital which started in late April, I visited 3 key areas - A&E, Crick ward and Elgar ward.  
In A&E my doctor was from the medics and his name was Sachin. The beside manners and care he provided was above expectations and he really seemed to care about everything he does for a patient. He was prompt and got things done without delay to ensure I would be at ease. Sachin had to perform a procedure however as it was not successful was able to get the procedure done by calling the theatres to get the anaesthetist to have a go to ensure things would be done. I can’t thank Sachin enough for being exceptionally kind, caring and attentive to my needs whilst under his care in A&E. Furthermore, thank you for the A&E radiology team for taking care of one of their own staff members with care and dignity and constantly checking to ensure I was ok and if I needed anything. It was not nice to be the patient and not be working with you but I’ll be back to work soon and we can all have a laugh about how much of a mess I looked!  
I was transferred to Crick ward later in the evening and I was left in the caring hands of Kerry who was my night shift nurse. She put me at ease with her calming personality and reassured me I can call if I need anything at all. She was in and out of the room the whole right doing observations and providing medication that I needed. Kerry made my evenings feel relaxed and safe when visitors were no longer allowed to be there. During the day in Crick I had a nurse called Dana. I have to say Dana, you really made me feel better and better about myself. You made not only me laugh but my mum and sister by being hilarious and making things a little lighter. I told anyone that came that I had the best nurse so far looking after me and they saw I felt a little more positive and had a smile on my face even though I was in a lot of pain still. Dana please carry on being yourself, you make a massive difference in a patients day in the hospital and you truly are an amazing human. Also shoutout to Michael who was coming in and out of the room during the day to do my observations alongside Dana - he was another individual who cares and tries to make his patient smile, a great asset to the team.  
Finally I ended up in Elgar ward on Sunday evening as I tested positive for Covid to my surprise. I had a lovely nurse in the evening although I have forgotten her name I think it was possibly Kristinna - a kind and lovely nurse who made sure I was settled in as I was transferred late night to Elgar ward. My day nurse Dave who looked after me during 2 day shifts was great. Attentive to my needs and ensured I was comfortable. He got my medication for me on time and tried to give best knowledge where possible and got doctors when I had a concern about my discharge plan. A big thank you to Premila who is the ward clerk who has arranged a follow up appointment for me to see the team in the outpatient clinic and also for being smiley face which is great when you are feeling a little low.  
Overall a massive thank you to everyone who has been part of my care in Northwick Park. I am home recovering now and look forward to returning to work and being part of another patients journey through our hospital.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

links.id: very well looked after and safe

title: Covid Clinic good experience
body: All the staff were incredibly helpful and friendly.  When I entered the clinic, I made a suggestion about putting an extra sign outside as I and several others were confused where to go in.  When I was coming out a few minutes later, someone was already putting up the sign.  That’s what I call proactive! The team fixing me the vaccination were so nice and made the experience painless and stress free. Thank you!

title: Surgery was good not so much now
body: Since joining the surgery approximately three years ago I always had great confidence and respect for it. Lately I am having some sort of problem with my prescriptions🤦‍♀️there is usually something missing or recently the prescription wasn’t done at all after requesting my meds. I was left again without pain meds which I need every day. It was sorted eventually but not after going over the bank holiday without them causing me a tremendous amount of pain. The ask first app also used to be good to use but again not lately. You can’t get an appointment for two weeks, this is useless when you need to see a gp asap. I have booked a face to face on there only to get to the surgery to be told it was a telephone consultation, which wasn’t the case. I see that the surgery says it’s still taking on new patients, it would be good if the patients you already have could rely on a service before taking on more new patients. There is one lady at the surgery that I can always rely on, she listens and sorts things out asap obviously it is harder to get an appointment with her but it is well worth it as long as it isn’t something urgent. It means if I can speak to her then I don’t have to keep explaining all my medical issues/ history as she knows me so well.

author: aoiy23
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: This toast was probably the best I have ever had.
body:
At the Day Surgery Unit in Craigavon, I spent the majority of the time waiting. One thing that can be improved upon is being informed before I arrived that I had a long wait before surgery started, I understand that there can be holds up but it just would be nice to be informed of this.  
I arrived in the morning, but all I did was fill out paperwork. I then had to wait until after lunchtime to be brought into surgery for a quick, thirty-minute procedure. Overall, waiting for this long wasn't enjoyable. However, I thought the nurses were excellent overall, especially when they brought me coffee and toast since I had been fasting all day. This toast was probably the best I have ever had.  
The registrar provided first-rate service and was great. Her operation skills were fantastic the staff couldn’t have done a better job with the care and treatment that they provided to me here!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Excellent Care
body: I had an MRI lunch time on Saturday 29 April 2023.  I cannot speak or regard the team more highly.  They were kind, respectful, pleasant and very very helpful.  I am a disabled pensioner and was treated like royalty.  They helped me get on the trolley which was no mean feat as I am a large lady. They made sure I was comfortable before I went into the tunnel and reassured me whilst I was in there.  When I came out they let me lay on the trolley a while before helping me get up.  They did not rush me at all.  I wish there were more people like them.  I was so very anxious and they helped me so much that it wasn’t as bad as I thought.  I would like to thank them so very very much and let them know how they helped me to not be so anxious and made me feel that I wasn’t a burden to them.  What a really lovely team.  I wish them all the luck in the world they deserve it.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Can't get appointment.
body:
Phoned last week for an appointment and was 32nd in the queue. 50 minutes later when I finally got through, I was told that no appointments were available and I could not pre-book appointments. The surgery was also closed in the afternoon for training. Told to phone next day.
Today I visited the Surgery to book an appointment. The receptionist told me that I could not book appointments in advance, I could only book on the day. She then said I should call in person the next day at 8am and wait in the queue to book the appointment. I didn't see any people in the waiting areas so I don't know what is going on at this surgery. I am now looking to transfer to another Surgery.

title: prescriptions
body: Almost every  prescription i have received I had somthing missing or i was been given thing i never asked for i have writen on the  prescriptions asking them to make sure all my item are sent to the pharmacy and guess what yep i have to ring them again to order the items i never received once i can understand but every time come on more care needs to be taken with peoples   prescriptions  people lives are in your hands

title: Wonderful gp
body:
I have been in contact with a particular lady dr for the last few months, regarding my iron levels and menopausal symptoms.

She has been wonderful, so friendly, she takes the time to listen and it really shows in how she talks to you how much she cares. 

I have never met her, we have just spoken on the phone several times and I liase through the surgery via the online consultation which I find invaluable.

I think the online consultation is a great idea to reach out to a gp knowing you will receive a call back.

This a great surgery and I feel very lucky to speak to such wonderful doctors, even at 6.30pm in the evening after I’m sure a very long day for them, they are still willing to listen attentively and reassure me.

Thank you so much.

title: Poor communication
body: They send text messages detailing unexpected news which should at least warrant a telephone call.  This also leads to no collaboration in treatment decisions. They follow Oxfordshire guidelines over NICE. They have updated records by uploading scans of corrections instead of correcting them. Some lovely staff remain. They do not take repeat prescriptions over the phone and you cannot order online for children and they have no plans to change this. Medication is only given a month at a time and it now takes 5 working days before you can return to collect. If it’s out of stock or there is a supply issue they won’t make a courtesy call to let you know. The automated message for the surgery before you can talk to a person is frustratingly long.

title: Very Poor
body:
I arrived at 8am with 11 people in front of me to try and get and appointment.
 At 8.15p I was told no appointment's today from a lovely receptionist who was clearly sorry I had to go to Corby Urgent Care under my circumstances.
My question is. Why was no appointment available at this early hour?? and what about the other 60 or so people trying to phone for an appointment  ??
Disgraceful service

title: Kind & Understanding GP
body: I visited the GP DR Hasnain with my parent and it was to deal with a condition that they did not want to discuss or accept. The doctor was so thorough asking lots of questions and doing lots of tests. She was so kind and understanding as she could see it was very upsetting. She went through all the things that were discussed and advised what tests were needed next and she discussed the probable diagnosis in a calm and easy manner that did not cause further distress. I cannot thank her enough as we have now got the process moving to get a full diagnosis and hopefully some help.

title: Awful practice with no communication
body: After raising an issue with the practice manager I was told that she would investigate and return to me by 19th of April. After setting the deadline herself i am still yet to hear a thing from her, unwilling take a call either. Very very poor and disappointing service.

title: Awful
body: I badly injured and bruised my hip and leg ,was sent in by ambulance, I had previously broken the same hip before, we were left waiting for 8 hours how disgusting, I asked for morphine got ignored, asked again, was given paracetamol no water I was told I had to get some, my partner had to walk to the end of the main corridor to get me some, I was told I had to have an X-ray, this did not happen I was just told to rest and to take painkillers and was sent on my way, I could have done this at home, the receptionist was rude so was the doctor that I saw for a few minutes, it was so obvious that she wasn’t listening, it was going in one ear and out the other, what a terrible experience.

readBy.name: Royal United Hospital Bath NHS Trust

title: Better to avoid
body: Always busy, it is almost impossible to speak with a doctor even over the phone, it can take 1 month to schedule an appointment and then it will be a super quick call where there is no time to speak.

author: Timothyvc23
title: ENT services
body:
Pre covid I was attending the Newry ent surgery on an 16 week cycle. Constantly hampered with narrow ear canals these ladies kept me sane and able to hear. Covid happened and I was left with no where to turn and almost deaf, found a local lady which offered some help but finally got back into the ENT surgery in banbridge medical centre and Julie has transformed my ears and canals back to health.  
Straight away on the first visit she was horrified to see the state of my ears and was concerned I would have needed to be hospitalised. Trials with several different creams and sprays we have now found a winning formula and the ears are great. I still attend every 8 weeks but thankfully Julie feels that over the next couple of visits we can push this back to 12/16 week visits.  
I cannot complement this service highly enough as I would have been in serious trouble without the staffs help.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Emergency advice to contact 111 service
body:
I was dubious about contacting the 111 service however, I was surprised to receive a appointment  within 30 minutes of making the call to the111 service.
The consultation I received from Dr ? was exceptional , drugs supplied and an appointment made to attend Chesterfield Royal Hospital the following day for follow up investigations.
A satisfied patient WMC, 111 Service and CRH.

title: Excellent care They saved my life.
body: Was rushed to Hospital with sepsis, The Ambulance crew were fantastic, A&E went above and beyond. Was transferred to icu for further monitoring and then moved to ward 402. I can’t thank all the Doctors, Nurses and everyone else that looked after me enough, their actions saved my life Thank you.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appalling in every way
body:
Cannot get an appointment have been trying for 3 weeks. Was given mis information by a receptionist who refused legal right to choose which hospital I wanted to be referred to. When I explained that it was my right to choose she got extremely argumentative and said that they would only refer me to one hospital (she also advised that their chosen hospital had a waiting list several months long). 

Not sure why this mis information was given but suggest staff receive training on patient rights and how to treat patients with respect. 

They have lots of posters up saying they want to be treated with respect. Next time I attend  the practice, I might take my own poster asking them to treat me with respect and answer my concerns honestly instead of giving inaccurate information.

I really feel sorry for vulnerable patients how will not be able to stand up for themselves.

Prescriptions are regularly wrong and the local chemist is even fed up of the amount of errors they're incurring.

How can a medical practice have so little regard for their patients?

title: Chaotic, Confused not fit for purpose
body: After waiting 2.5 months after an MRI to speak to consultant with horrific Gynae bleeding causing me to go anaemic every time. Nov 22. She placed me on the list for surgery. (Gynae) had a pre op Feb 23. Thinking I would get a surgery date within the 3 month pre op window… nope. Got another random out patients appoint ( utterly confused by it)… with another consultant… which i asked to change as couldnt get to appoint. Heard nothing more….. no surgery date, no further appointment with consultant… just left hanging and suffering. With a hectic job and two young kids to care for I dont think i can carry on. I dont think anyone communicates with eachother…its just utter chaos.

author: Maw stark
title: Diabetes
body:
I've had diabetes for a few years and I thought I had it well under control but all the finger picks have taken there toll and the skin on my fingers is badly damaged and sore. I asked if I qualify for the libre 2 I received an email this morning and filled in what I had to and I'm just waiting on it coming and have my on line meeting for instructions on how to use it.  
I'll keep you updated.

readBy.name: Office of Annabelle Ewing, MSP for Cowdenbeath

author: Colww35
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: All staff do a fantastic job
body:
My Level off care in Discharge lounge has been great everyone treated the same and no problems at all . The only downside is waiting on Prescriptions No other issues all staff treated me well and all are first class at all they do for you can't complain at all. All staff do a fantastic job in my Opinion and could not ask for better.  
Thank you to everyone involved in my care.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: guidewp37
title: They deserve to get a mention because they were very kind
body:
I went to the clinic yesterday it was the women’s continence clinic, in the Omagh primary care complex. It was relating to my bladder. I met nurse Jane and she was a very pleasant lovely little girl, she made me feel very relaxed, and she explained everything she was doing to me and Carolyn, the other nurse, she was equally good and lovely and they made me very much at ease, and I want to say thank you very much to those girls.  
I was waiting over two years for that appointment. I had forgotten about it to be totally honest because it was such a long wait, when I got the letter I thought what’s this all about and had to read it again. It was the incontinence clinic. I’m going to have a follow up appointment at some point. They explained everything and told me what I should do and what not to do etc.  
They deserve to get a mention because they were very kind. The two girls were so nice to me .

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Colww35
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Very professional in every aspect
body: Treated very well in Hematology Ward lovely Doctors Nurses and all members off staff could not have asked for better. Very professional in every aspect off there role in which they do.  The ward is very tidy clean and that is all down to team work could not have any better.  Great experience in the ward took me a while to get used to everyone but I am so at home now with everyone.  The food is great but I have been here to long and it's is getting a bit to much for me just want to get home soon.  But thank you to everyone for my level of care.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: not great at all
body: gp refered me to ramsgate house because i was suffering greatly with my mental health they refered me on to living well salford which is ok in itself but would not solve psychological problems also it would have been nice if they consulted with me on there intetions instead of being refered on to living well

title: Unable to get a physical appointment
body: Need a urgent appointment stroke survivor. Dizzy could fall. 45 in call then no app. 111 app 14 in queue.  Next day gp 32 in queue. Gp call back pm. Call again after 14.00pm. Told really busy. Need to come to surgery as Practice Manager doesn't take calls. Have to physically come to surgery to fill in form to complain. Told Gp could ring up to 6.30 pm to discuss my symptoms. Very emotional as bereathed.  No empathy from reception. Just Told over and over again everyone in same boat Busy. Then got phone call from lovely sympathetic Gp . Seen immediately. This surgery has a new second surgery . Old surgery empty when I arrived. I know primary care is busy but this surgery is lacking in providing appointments. Unapproachable and dismissive over the phone. The clinical staff are wonderful when you can eventually see them. I can't fault the eventual care i recieved. But today I was frightened my Stoke was extending. Something needs to be done so patients can be seen in a timely manner. I apologised to reception to the reception staff when physically at the surgery. But I was able to do that rather than go to A/E which was my next destination

title: Terrible Practice
body: terrible experience, I had a prolonged sore throat for nearly a month, I was repeatedly told by the practice that it wasn’t an emergency. It ended up turning into a quinsy, so then unfortunately I had to go in to a.e and spend nearly two days in hospital on a drip recovering from having the abscess in my throat drained. Only then for montgomery house to call me and tell me I should go to hospital to get my throat looked at once I had already been discharged.
